TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to discuss the Austudy scheme introduced on 1 January. This scheme is just another example of this Government's never-ending ability to get things wrong. It has been one of the biggest issues in the Forde electorate over the past few months. Every time I have received a complaint from a constituent I have written to the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) to make her aware of it. On each occasion I have been surprised to receive a standard reply referring to the disastrous Priority One program. Has this Government no shame, or is it simply blinded by its own propaganda? The young people of Australia and their parents are well aware of the failure of the Priority One program to deliver the tens of thousands of promised traineeships. They do not want to hear another word about it. They remember the glossy brochures, the hyped-up advertising campaign and the billboards which simply read:

SPEECH.PARA: Young Australians should be seen, heard, educated, employed, encouraged, respected and all treated as if they're the future of this country.

The billboards gave no indication of how young people or employers could become involved in the program. But then again, Priority One was strangled by red tape from the beginning. It probably would have taken a series of billboards with fine print to explain all the rules associated with the scheme. The replies from the Minister on the Austudy scheme also contained the usual bureaucratic references to strategies, rationalisation and reorganisation, et cetera, complete with a promise that everything will be right after 1989.

I would like to concentrate on one bureaucratic decision, namely to use students' ages as the criterion for payment of secondary allowances rather than the previous basis of their grade or form. Before the change, allowances were paid to all students in year 11 regardless of their age at the time. I cannot see any sense behind the decision, but it smacks of the general centralist approach of the Hawke Government. It discriminates against my State of Queensland, the Northern Territory and the less populous States of South Australia and Western Australia. In Queensland, 43 per cent of year 11 students are aged 15 or less. The same figure applies in Western Australia, while in South Australia it is 45 per cent. In the Northern Territory it is 36 per cent. This contrasts with the situation in Victoria, where only 2 1/2 per cent of year 11 students are aged 15 or less. The Australian Capital Territory has 3 per cent, New South Wales 4 per cent and Tasmania 9 per cent.

This means that students and their parents in Victoria, the Australian Capital Territory, New South Wales and Tasmania are far better off than their counterparts in Queensland, Western Australia, South Australia and the Northern Territory. The Australian Capital Territory's comparatively low figure of 3 per cent may be significant in terms of a continuing centralist approach. The discrimination against Queensland students in favour of those in the Australian Capital Territory in the tertiary education sector is well documented. There are almost three times as many tertiary places per 100,000 population in the Australian Capital Territory as there are in my home State. Perhaps it was one of the Minister's advisers who proposed the change in secondary allowances under Austudy. Perhaps it was the Minister herself because, after all, she is a senator for the Australian Capital Territory. Regardless of who it was, it is a pity that they did not look at the situation throughout the whole of Australia prior to drawing up the Austudy provisions.

The 43 per cent of students and their parents in Queensland who are affected should not be out of pocket because the Commonwealth Department of Education considers that they are a grade ahead of what someone else says is the ideal level for their age. There will always be arguments among educationalist as to the ideal age for children to begin school. It needs to be remembered that those who will not qualify for assistance in year 11 are missing out because of decisions their parents made ten years ago. One could almost describe it as bordering on retrospectivity. The guidelines are not logical on that basis and neither are they logical when the general cost of education is considered. The final two years of high school in every State and Territory are the years of specialisation. At the end of Year 10 we ask students to choose a program which will hopefully lead to a life-long career. Consequently, the subjects studied in the final two years are much more complex than those in the previous years. Sometimes specialised equipment is needed as well, and there are the financial pressures on parents as the students make the transition from being young teenagers to young adults.

The Minister for Education has said she would like to encourage young people to stay at school to complete Year 12 to improve their chances of getting a job. No one would argue with that. It has been long recognised that the provision of allowances for the final two years of high school might help in that regard. But the Government has failed to recognise that it costs parents just as much to keep a student aged 15 in Year 11 as it does for a student of 16. The Minister has promised to monitor the situation and I plead with her on behalf of the parents of Queensland to remove this discrimination from the Austudy provisions. I have written many letters to her on behalf of my constituents. I hope she will take them into account.

Mr Ruxton today seemed surprised by the result of the Poll.

According to the poll he is saying that if 64 per cent of Australians disagree with him those people-Australians who live in those suburbs-are not Australians and they do not agree with the rest of Australia; they are somehow different people. This man's views and comments are most alarming. Obviously he speaks from the top of his head and does not think about what he says. He is an absolute embarrassment to the Returned Services League. The man should learn to think before he speaks. In winding up let me say this: The most pleasing thing about the poll is that it says one thing to Mr Ruxton: `You are wrong, wrong, wrong'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Frederick Walter Collard, who died on 1 December 1986, was born in 1912 in Western Australia and represented the electorate of Kalgoorlie from 1961 to 1975. I had the pleasure of working for Fred in many campaigns. His background was that of a common man-a trade union official with the Australian Workers Union and a wartime airman, rising to the rank of leading aircraftsman before his discharge in 1946. That background was to follow him throughout his parliamentary career. Reading the Hansard record of his speeches, one is struck by the wide range of matters in which he found time to be interested. His concern for the average Australian was continually expressed in all he did. All the topics he rose to address followed Australian Labor Party policy to look after those least able to look after themselves, to better the lot of all members of the community, whether from his electorate or the wider community. In that regard, his work with parliamentary delegations overseas was highly respected. He represented the Parliament and the people of Australia in Lima, Abidjan, Geneva, New Zealand and Tokyo.

SPEECH.PARA: Fred Collard often spoke on pedestrian subjects, but in a concerned manner; in all areas of social welfare; education, especially that of isolated children and their special needs; and Aboriginals in relation to business development as proposed in the States Grants (Aboriginal Advancement) Bill of 1968. He was a champion for reform and the maintenance or upgrading of the dignity of his fellows. As further evidence of his wide-ranging interests, he was to speak in 1966 of the benefits to isolated communities of television, thereby pre-dating the then Minister, Mr Staley, by some 10 years. However, he never made the extravagant promises that Mr Staley made. He was instrumental in swaying the Caucus of the need for special consideration for the gold mining industry in relation to gold tax. I had a special affinity with him in that area.

Long time Press gallery journalist and political encyclopaedian, Ian Fitchett, recalls that Arthur Calwell was so sure of the worth of Fred Collard and Kalgoorlie that a week before the 1963 election he vigorously electioneered in Kalgoorlie-probably to the detriment of the rest of the country, because it was a campaign he lost. More often in opposition than in government he was a debater of terrier-like qualities and never let a chance go by to show up the Government, giving great support to his leaders. I and my staff extend our sympathy to his family, especially his daughter Judy who resides in Kalgoorlie.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 28 November 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has Telecom participated in meetings of a Product Protection Committee; if so, (a) what is the purpose of the committee and (b) have senior management and the Telecom Board of Commissioners been kept informed of its activities, including having access to the minutes of the committee and any sub-committee.
(2) Did he state in a letter to me, dated 18 August 1986, that Telecom has no Product Protection Committee or Product Protection Group in the Directories area.
(3) Does he intend to take any action if such a committee exists.
(4) What proportion of Telecom's annual profit is derived from commissions it receives on its Yellow Pages directories service.
(5) What has been the net annual profit from Telecom's Yellow Pages in each year since 1980-81.

(6) Why did Telecom, when making the payment of about $US1 million to the owners of Australian Directory Services (ADS) in connection with their acquisition of Directories Australia make the payment through a reduction in royalty payments to Telecom to Directories Australia instead of ADS, which had allegedly suffered significant additional costs in developing alternative selling records as a result of Directories Australia's behaviour.
(7) If ADS did incur additional costs and part, or all, of the $1.5m was compensation for that loss, why was it paid to Directories Australia as capital rather than to ADS as revenue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based on advice from the Australian Telecommunications Commission, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There is no ``Product Protection Committee'' in the Directories area of Telecom. Telecom, on its own account, and in conjunction with its contractor has from time to time engaged in the normal business of competitive analysis, but at all times within the bounds of normal industry ethical standards. Senior Telecom and contractor management form a group called the Yellow Pages Management Group (YPMG) whose purpose is to provide overall direction to the management of the Yellow Pages and to approve expenditure on items such as Promotion and Advertising and Market Research. Product protection is usually an item on the agenda of YPMG meetings.
(2) Yes.
(3) There is no such committee (See reply to (1) above).
(4) and (5) Telecom regards details of profit derived from the Yellow Pages directory service as commercial-in-confidence.

(6) Telecom contributed to the settlement by an offset in royalties as a matter of convenience to Telecom. As no budget had been allowed for this event, Telecom took the view that it was simpler to effect payment by issuing a credit note to Directories (Aust) (who had recently been taken over by the owners of ADS) which allowed them to offset the about $US1 million against royalty payments.

(7) Telecom did not co-operate with Australian Directory Services (ADS) to transfer a revenue payment to a capital payment. There was no discussion to this effect between Telecom and ADS. Telecom was not a party to, nor was it aware of Australian Directory Services internal accounting procedures which would have resulted in tax benefits by ADS.
